Authors:
Wataru Aoki, Raymond Archambault, Jean A. Bérubé, Yves
LamoureuxJean, Masaki Fukuda, Akiyoshi Yamada
Title:
Tricholoma alpinus sp. nov., found under the five-needle
pines in the alpine and subalpine zones in Japan
Keywords:
AGARICALES, ECTOMYCORRHIZAL FUNGI, MULTI-GENES PHYLOGENY,
RELICT SPECIES, TRICHOLOMATACEAE
Abstract:
Alpine regions in Japan are characterized by the Siberian
dwarf pine, Pinus pumila. Although these regions are conserved as
national parks due to their unique biome, few reports of the fungal
biota are available. We examined mushroom fungi under such vegetation
and found a unique yellowish-capped Tricholoma species. Multi-locus
molecular phylogenetic analyses and morphological observation of the
specimens showed that the Tricholoma species share the common ancestor
with T. fumosoluteum from North America. The Japanese yellowish-capped
T. aff. fumosoluteum had larger basidiospores and basidia and shorter
pileipellis hyphae compared to T. fumosoluteum. Therefore, we describe
T. aff. fumosoluteum as T. alpinum.
